Irish: Bái mesca mór for Ulto fecht n-and i nSliab Fúait. Docuridar didiu immarbága móra ocus comrama eturro .i. etir Chonall ocus Coinculaind ocus Lóegaire. “Tucaid dam-sa” ar Conall “inchind Me[i]ssgegra co ro-acilliur ócu na comram.” Ba bés d’ Ultaib ind inbaid sin cach curaid nomarbdais ar galaib óenfhir nogatta a n-inchind assa cendaib ocus commesct[h]a áel airthib co ndénad líathróite crúade díb. Ocus intan nobítis i n-immarbáig nó chomramaib dobertis dóib co mbítis inna lámaib.
English: Once upon a time the men of Ulster were greatly intoxicated in Sliab Fúait. Thence there arise great contentions and comparison of trophies between them, even between Conall and Cuchulinn and Loegaire. “Bring me,” said Conall, “the brain of Mesgegra, so that I may talk to the competing warriors.” At that time it was a custom with the men of Ulster to take the brains out of the head of every warrior whom they slew in single combat, and to mix lime with them, so that they were made into hard balls. And whenever they were in contention or at comparison of trophies, these were brought to them, so that they had them in their hands.
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: A great feast was made for the men of Ulster to meet in Slieve Fuaid. A record was made of a great gathering and of a convention, namely, between Connall and Conculainn and Lóegaire. “I have,” said Connall, “the right of Messgra as was granted to me by the conventions.” It was a custom with the Ulstermen in that attack that every champion who was not a single combatant would be taken captive and mixed with noble women so that they would make hard balls of them. And whenever they were in a gathering or convention, they were given to them to be in their hands.
gemma_T0.2_K40_P0.85: A great feast was made for the men of Ulster to meet in Slieve Fuaid. A record was made of a great gathering and of a convention, namely, between Connall and Conculainn and Lóegaire. “I have,” said Connall, “the right of Messgra as was granted to me by the conventions.” It was a custom of the Ulstermen in that attack that every champion would be killed on the points of single spears, and their bodies would be mixed with grey stones so that hard balls would be made of them. And whenever they were in a gathering or convention, gifts were given to them so that they would be in their hands.
gemma_T0.5_K30_P0.85: A great feast was made for the men of Ulster to meet in Slieve Fuaid. A record was made of a great gathering and of a convention, namely, between Connall and Conculainn and Lóegaire. “I have,” said Connall, “the right of Messgra as was granted to me by the conventions.” It was a custom of the Ulstermen in that attack that every champion would be killed on the points of single spears, and their bodies would be mixed with grey stones so that hard balls would be made of them. And whenever they were in a gathering or convention, gifts were given to them so that they would be in their hands.
gemma_T1.0_K40_P0.9: A great feast was made for the men of Ulster to meet in Slieve Fuaid. A record was made of a great gathering and of a convention, namely, between Connall and Conculainn and Lóegaire. “I have,” said Connall, “the right of Messgra as was granted to me by the convention.” It was a custom with the Ulstermen in that attack that every champion who was not a single combatant would be taken captive and mixed with noble women so that they would make hard balls of them. And whenever they were in a gathering or convention, they would be given into their hands.

Irish: “Maith, a Conall,” ar Chonchobuir, “na co ndernat óic na comram écht fón innas-[s]a ar galaib óinfhir, nídat túalngi comram frim-sa.” “Is fir ón,” ar Conall.
English: “Well, O Conall,” said Chonchobuir, “until the competing warriors perform a deed like this in single combat, they are not capable of comparing trophies with me.” “That is true,” said Conall.
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: Good, Conall,” said Conchobhar, “whoever did the deed of this hosting is not a lawful host for us. It is not a firm hosting against me.” “It is true,” said Conall.
gemma_T0.2_K40_P0.85: Good, Conall,” said Conchobhar, “whoever did the deed of this hosting is not a man to be trusted, he is not a lawful host. It is true,” said Conall.
gemma_T0.5_K30_P0.85: Good, Conall,” said Conchobhar, “whoever did the deed of this hosting is not a lawful host for us. It is not a firm hosting against you.” “It is true,” said Conall.
gemma_T1.0_K40_P0.9: Good, Conall,” said Conchobhar, “whoever made the cause of this meeting a harsh burden on my people, it is not a lasting cause for me.” “It is true,” said Conall.

Irish: Doratad íarum forsin forud fora mbíd dogrés ind inchind. Luid cách a lethi arnabárach dia cluchiu. Dolluid dano Cet mac Matach do chúairt ectra la Ulto. Béist ass andsam robói i nHérinn in Cet. Ised dolluid-side dar faidchi na hFúait  ocus tri láechcind leis do Ultaib.
English: Then the brain was put upon the shelf upon which it was always kept. On the morrow every one went his own way to his sport. Then Cet, the son of Matu, went upon a round of adventures in Ulster. This Cet was the most troublesome pest that was in Ireland. This is the way he went, across the green of Fúait , having with him three warriors’ heads of the men of Ulster.
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: She carried away spoils and treasures from every place. It was a wretched death for a victorious warrior. Cet mac Matach came on an extra journey to Ulster. Cet was heard speaking rudely in Ireland. It was a similar fate that befell the men of Fál and three champions with him in Ulster.
gemma_T0.2_K40_P0.85: She carried away spoils and treasures from every place. It was a wretched death for a victorious warrior. Cet mac Matach came on an extra journey to Ulster. Cet was heard speaking rudely in Ireland. It was a similar fate that befell the men of Fál and three champions with him in Ulster.
gemma_T0.5_K30_P0.85: She carried away spoils and treasures from every place. It was a wretched death for a victorious warrior. Cet mac Matach came on an extra journey to Ulster. Cet was heard speaking rudely in Ireland. It was a similar fate that befell the men of Fál and three champions with him in Ulster.
gemma_T1.0_K40_P0.9: She carried away spoils and treasures from every place. It was a wretched death for a victorious warrior. Cet mac Matach came on an extra journey to Ulster. Cet was heard speaking rudely in Ireland. It was a similar fate that befell the men of Fál and three champions with him in Ulster.

Irish: Fecht and didiu dolluid-seom intí Cet sair co tuc tánai mbó a Feraib Ross. Donarraid i n-íarmóracht Ulaid ina diaid. Doriachtatar dano Connachtai dond leith aile dia thessarcain-seom. Fechair cath eturro. Dolluid Conchubur féin issin cath. Conid andsin gádatar mná Connacht do Conall tuidecht for leith do déscin a delba dóib. Fobíth ní rabi for talmain delb duini amail deilb Conchobuir .i. etir chruth ocus deilb ocus dechelt, etir mét ocus córe ocus cutrummae, etir rosc ocus fholt ocus gile, etir gáis ocus álaig ocus erlabra, etir erriud ocus áne ocus écosc, etir arm ocus immad ocus orddan, etir gnáis ocus gaisced ocus chenél. Nírbo lochtach tra intí Conall. A comairli immorro in Cheit rogabsat na mná ailgis do Chonchobur. Luid íarum for leth a óinur dia déscin dona mnáib.
English: Once then Cet went eastwards until he took a drove of cows from the men of the Rosses. The men of Ulster overtook him in pursuit after him. Then the men of Connaught came up from the other side to rescue him. A battle is fought between them. Conall himself went into the battle. And it was then that the women of Connaught begged Conall to come aside so that they might see his shape. For there was not on earth the shape of a human being like the shape of Conchobar, both for beauty and figure and dress, for size and symmetry and proportion, for eye and hair and whiteness, for wisdom and manners and eloquence, for raiment and nobleness and equipment, for weapons and wealth and dignity, for bearing and valour and race. That Conall was faultless indeed. However, it was by the advice of Cet that the women importuned Conchobar. Then he went aside alone to be seen by the women.
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: Fecht and constantly flourished the dwellings of Cet before the cattle of the Fir Bolg came to Ireland. Donnraid pursued in the aftermath of the men of Ulster. Connacht was plundered from them, taking half their tribute with them. A great battle will be fought. Conchubur himself will fall in that battle. Then the women of Connacht were given to Conall as a pledge for half their tribute. It is said there was no land-portion like the portion of Conchubur, namely, between truth and skill and hospitality, between wine and food and brightness, between speech and justice and counsel, between redness and whiteness and purity, between slaughter and honour and revenge, between weapons and praise and judgment, between beauty and valour and kinship. There was no fault with Conall’s share. To repay the great sorrow of Cet, the women were given to Conchubur. It was then taken for half his tribute for the women.
gemma_T0.2_K40_P0.85: Fecht and constantly flourished the dwellings of Cet before the cattle of the Fir Bolg came to Ireland. Donnraid pursued in the aftermath of the men of Ulster. Connacht was plundered from them, taking half their tribute with them. A great battle will be fought. Conchubor himself will fall in that battle. Then the women of Connacht were given to Conall as a pledge for half their tribute. It is said there was no land-portion like the portion of Conchubor, namely, between truth and skill and hospitality, between wine and food and brightness, between speech and justice and order, between redness and whiteness and purity, between slaughter and honour and revenge, between weapons and wisdom and judgment, between beauty and valour and kinship. There was no fault with Conall’s share. To repay the great sorrow of Cet, the women were given to Conchubor. It was then taken for half his tribute for the women.
gemma_T0.5_K30_P0.85: Fecht and constantly flourished the dwellings of Cet before the cattle of the Fir Bolg came to Ireland. Donnraid pursued in the aftermath of the men of Ulster after him. Connacht was plundered from them, leaving the other half to their share. A great battle will be fought. Conchubur himself flourished in that battle. Then the women of Connacht were given to Conall as a pledge for half of their share. It is said there was no land-portion for a man equal to Conchubur’s portion – between form and share and tribute, between wealth and right and nobility, between redness and whiteness and brightness, between wind and cliffs and nobility, between slaughter and beauty and swiftness, between weapon and skill and order, between kinship and valour and generation. There was no fault with Conall’s share. To balance the loss of Cet, the women pledged themselves to Conchubur. It was then for half of his honour that he gave it to the women.
gemma_T1.0_K40_P0.9: Fecht and constantly flourished the dwellings of Cet; so came the cattle-raids of the men of Ferra Ross. Donnraid pursued in the aftermath of the men of Ulster. Connacht was plundered from them, and half another tribute was taken from them. A great battle will be fought. Conchubur himself flourished in that battle. Then the women of Connacht were given to Conall as a pledge for half of their tribute. It is said there was no land-portion for a man equal to Conchubur’s portion – between form and substance and nobility, between wealth and worth and excellence, between redness and whiteness and brightness, between speech and justice and wisdom, between strength and peace and lineage, between weapon and skill and order, between beauty and heroism and kinship. There was no fault in Conall’s dealings. To repay the sorrow of Cet, the women offered their pledges to Conchubur. Thereafter, half of their wealth was given to the women as a pledge.

Irish: Dolluid Cet immorro co mbúi etir na mná immedón. Nosindlethar Cet inchind Mesgegra isin tábaill ocus nosteilc conidtarla immullach Conall co mbátar a dá trían inna chind ocus co torchairseom isa cend, co tarla fri lár. Focherddat Ulaid chuci conidrucsat ó Chet. For brú Átha Daire Dá Báeth is and dorochair Conall. Atá a lige and baile i torchair ocus corthe fria chend ocus corthe fria chossa.
English: Cet, however, went until he was in the midst of the women. He adjusts the brain of Mesgegra in the sling, and throws it so that it hit the crown of Conall’s head, so that two-thirds of it entered his head, so that he fell upon his head forward to the ground. The men of Ulster ran towards him, and carried him off from Cet. On the brink of the ford of Daire Dá Báeth it was that Conall fell. His grave is there where he fell, and a pillar-stone at his head, and another at his feet.
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: Cet committed a great sin with the women of the gathering. Cet was easily overcome by Mesgegra in the playing of the game, and a great host was gathered around Conall with boats for his three scores and with a cause for his victory, until it happened in the middle. The men of Ulster were angered by what Cet had done. It was a hardship for Átha Daire to have two Báeths, and Conall was a dark warrior. He released them to town and struck at his side and struck at his feet.
gemma_T0.2_K40_P0.85: Cet committed a great sin with the women of the gathering. Cet was easily defeated by Mesgegra in the playing-field and a story is told that Conall drove them mad with a boat of three in their tribe and with a piercing cry in their tops, until it happened in the middle. The men of Ulster were angered by this deed of Cet. It was a great burden for Átha Daire and the two Báeths, and Conall was a dark warrior. He let them go to town and strike at their tops and strike at their feet.
gemma_T0.5_K30_P0.85: Cet committed a great sin with the women of the gathering. Cet was easily overcome by Mesgegra in the playing of the game, and a great host was gathered around Conall with boats for his three scores and with a cause for his victory, until it happened in the middle. The men of Ulster were angered by what Cet had done. It is a shame for the fortress of Átha Daire, for Dá Báeth and for the dark deed of Conall. He is released into the town, striking at his side and striking at his feet.
gemma_T1.0_K40_P0.9: Cet committed a great sin with the women of the gathering. Cet was easily defeated by Mesgegra in the playing-field and a story is told that Conall drove them mad with a boat of three in their tribe and with a piercing cry in their tops, until it happened in the middle. The men of Ulster were angered by this deed of Cet. It was a great burden for Átha Daire and the two Báeths, and a dark deed of Conall. He let them go to town and cut off their heads and cut off their feet.

Irish: Maidid tra for Crích Ross  co Sciaig Aird na Con. Dobertar Ulaid sair doridisi co Áth Daire Dá Báeth. “Mo brith-se ass!” ar Conall. “Dobér ríge nUlad do neoch nombéra connici mo thech.” “Notbér-sa,” ar Cend Berraide, ar a gilla fadéin. Dobeir-side lomain imme ocus nombeir for a muin co Arddachad Emain Macha. Maidid a chride isin gillu. Conid de sin atá ‘ríge Cind Berraide for Ultaib’ .i. in rí for a muin leth ind lái.
English: The men of Crích Ross are then routed to Scé Aird na Con. The men of Ulster are driven eastwards again to the ford of Daire Dá Báeth. “Let me be carried out of this!” said Conall. “I shall give the kingship of Ulster to anyone who will carry me as far as my house.” “I will carry thee,” said Cenn Berraide, his own attendant. He puts a cord around him and carries him upon his back to Ardachad of the Emain Macha . The attendant’s heart broke within him. Hence is the saying over Ulster,’ ‘Cenn Berraide’s kingship over Ulster,’ to wit, the king upon his back for (only ) half the day.
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: They went to Críoch Ross and to Sciaig Aird na Con. Ulster was overrun with violence at Áth Daire Dá Báeth. “My birth is from this!” said Conall. “Let the kingship of Ulster be given to the one who avenges my household.” “I will avenge him,” said Cend Berraide, and his young servant. They took a hound with them and went to Arddachad Emain Macha. His heart was in his throat. From that comes the saying ‘the kingship of Cend Berraide in Ulster’ – that is, a king for a day.
gemma_T0.2_K40_P0.85: They went eastward to Críoch Ross as far as Sciaig Aird na Con. Ulster was stirred to violent hostility towards Áth Daire Dá Báeth. “My birth is from this!” said Conall. “Let the kingship of Ulster be given to the newest man among us in my stead.” “I shall be that man,” said Cend Berraide, with his long-lived attendant. He took a hound with him and went eastward to Arddachad Emain Macha. His heart was in his throat. Hence it is said ‘the kingship of Cend Berraide over Ulster’ – that is, a king in his stead for half a day.
gemma_T0.5_K30_P0.85: They went eastward to Críoch Ross as far as Sciaig Aird na Con. Ulster was stirred to violent hostility towards Áth Daire Dá Báeth. “My birth is from this!” said Conall. “Let the kingship of Ulster be given to the newest man among us in my stead.” “I shall be that man,” said Cend Berraide, with his long-lived attendant. He took a hound with him and went to Arddachad Emain Macha. His heart was in his throat. Hence it is said ‘the kingship of Cend Berraide over Ulster’ – that is, a king for half a day in his stead.
gemma_T1.0_K40_P0.9: They went eastward to Críoch Ross as far as Sciaig Aird na Con. Ulster was stirred to violent hostility towards Áth Daire Dá Báeth. “My birth is from this!” said Conall. “Let the kingship of Ulster be given to the newest man among us in my stead.” “I shall be that man,” said Cend Berraide, with his long-lived attendant. He took a hound with him and went to Arddachad Emain Macha. His heart was in his throat. Hence it is said ‘the kingship of Cend Berraide over Ulster’ – that is, the kingship for his own life, for half a day.

Irish: Conócbad trá in debaid ón tráth co araile dar éis in ríg. Co ráimid for Ulto íarsin.
English: However, the fight was kept up after the king from one hour of the day to the same hour on the next day, after which the men of Ulster were routed.
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: He knew the strand in the debate from the strand until another time after the king. Who shall we say for Ulster afterwards?
gemma_T0.2_K40_P0.85: He knew the strand in the debate from the strand until another time after the king. Who shall we say for Ulster afterwards?
gemma_T0.5_K30_P0.85: He knew the strand in the debate from the strand until another time after the king. Who shall we say for Ulster afterwards?
gemma_T1.0_K40_P0.9: He knew the strand in the debate from the strand until another time after the king. Who shall we say for Ulster afterwards?

Irish: Doberar tra a liaig co Conall .i. Fingen. Iss éside nofhinnad don díaid nothéiged don tig in lín nobíd i ngalur ’sin tig ocus cech galar nobíd and. “Maith,” or Fingen, “dia taltar in chloch as do chind biat marb fo chétóir. Mani tucthar ass immorro, not-ícfaind ocus bid athis duit.” “Is asso dún” ar Ulaid “ind athis oldás a éc som.”
English: In the meantime his physician was brought to Conall, even Fingen. ’Tis he who would know from the smoke that arose from a house how many were ill in the house, and every disease that was in it. “Well,” said Fingen, “if the stone is taken out of thy head, thou wilt be dead forthwith. If it is not taken out, however, I would heal thee, but it will be a blemish for thee.” “It is easier for us,” said the men of Ulster, “to bear the blemish than his death.”
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: A dart was thrown at Lugaid by Conall, namely Fingen. It is on his side that healing is for the wound that was inflicted on the house in the bright linen, and every disease that was inflicted. “Good,” said Fingen, “if the stone is removed from your skin, you will be dead under a shroud. Many are taken from the otherworld, not-unseen and it will be with you.” “That is true,” said the Ulstermen, “and it is old that is said.”
gemma_T0.2_K40_P0.85: A dart was thrown at Lugaid by Conall, namely Fingen. It is on his side, a refuge for the wretched, for the house in the bright valley and every disease that is not bright. “Good,” said Fingen, “if the stone is removed from your skin, you will be dead under a shroud. Many are taken from tomorrow, not-unseen and it will be with you.” “That is true,” said the Ulstermen, “and it is old that is said.”
gemma_T0.5_K30_P0.85: A dart was thrown at Lugaid by Conall, namely Fingen. It is on his side, a refuge for the wretched, for the house in the bright valley and every disease that is not bright. “Good,” said Fingen, “if the stone is removed from your skin, you will be dead under a shroud. Many are taken from tomorrow, not-unseen and it will be with you.” “That is true,” said the Ulstermen, “and it is old that is said.”
gemma_T1.0_K40_P0.9: A dart was thrown at Lugaid by Conall, namely Fingen. It is on his side that healing is for every affliction and for the house of the noble, and for every noble affliction. “Good,” said Fingen, “if the stone is removed from your skin, you will be dead under a shroud. Many are taken from tomorrow, not-unseen and it will be with you.” “That is true,” said the Ulstermen, “and it is old that is said.”

Irish: Ro-íccad íarum a chend ocus rofúaged co snáth óir, ar ba cumma dath fuilt Conchobuir ocus dath inn óir. Ocus asbert in liaig fri Conall co mbeth i fomtin .i. ar ná tísad a fherg dó ocus ná digsed for ech ocus ná etraiged mnái [ocus ná rocaithed biad] co anfeta ocus ná rethed.
English: His head was then healed; and it was stitched with thread of gold, for the colour of Conall’s hair was the same as the colour of gold. And the physician said to Conall that he should be on his guard lest anger should come on him, and that he should not mount a horse, that he should not have connexion with a woman, that he should not eat food greedily, and that he should not run.
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: She was again inflamed by his beauty, and she was yearning for him like a thread of gold, for the colour of Conchobar’s blood was bright and her own was gold. And the leech said to Conall that it was a sign of madness, namely, that she would not allow his clothing to be taken from him, nor a horse to be driven before him, nor women to approach [nor food to be given] without permission, nor to be spoken to.
gemma_T0.2_K40_P0.85: She was again inflamed by his beauty, and she was yearning for him like a thread of gold, for the colour of Conchobar’s blood was bright and her own was gold. And the leech said to Conall that it was a sign of madness, namely, that she would not allow his clothing to be taken from him, nor a horse to be driven before him, nor women to approach [nor food to be given] without permission, nor to be spoken to.
gemma_T0.5_K30_P0.85: She was again inflamed by his beauty, and she was yearning for him like a thread of gold, for the colour of Conchobar’s blood was bright and her own was gold. And the leech said to Conall that it was a sign of madness, namely, that she would not allow his clothing to be taken from him, nor a horse to be driven before him, nor women to approach [nor food to be given] without permission, nor to be spoken to.
gemma_T1.0_K40_P0.9: She was again inflamed by his beauty, and she was yearning for him like a thread of gold, for the colour of Conchobar’s blood was bright and her own was gold. And the leech said to Conall that it was a sign of madness, namely, that she would not allow his clothing to be taken from him, nor a horse to be driven before him, nor women to approach [nor food to be given] without permission, nor to be spoken to.

Irish: Robói dano isin chuntabairt sin céin robo beó .i. secht mbliadna ocus nírbo engnamaid, acht a airisium inna shuidi nammá .i. naco cúala Críst do chrochad do Iudaidib. Tánic and side crith mór forsna dúli ocus rochrithnaig nem ocus talam la mét in gníma darónad and  .i. Ísu Críst mac Dé bí do chrochad cen chinaid. “Cráet so?” ar Conall fria drúid. “Cia olc mór dogníther isind lathiu-sa indiú?” “Is fir ón ém,” ar in drúi. “Is mór in gním sin,” ar Conall. “In fer sin dano” ar in drúi “i n-óenaidchi rogein ocus rogenis-[s]iu .i. i n-ocht calde Enair cen cop inund bliadain.”
English: In that doubtful state, then, he was as long as he lived, even seven years; and he was not capable of action, but remained in his seat only, until he heard that Christ had been crucified by the Jews. At that time a great trembling came over the elements, and the heavens and the earth shook with the enormity of the deed that was then done, even Jesus Christ, the Son of the living God, to be crucified without guilt. “What is this?” said Conall to his druid. “What great evil is being done on this day?” “That is true, indeed,” said the druid [who then tells the story of the Crucifixion ]. “Awful is that deed,” said Conall. “That man, now,” said the druid, “was born in the same night in which thou wast born, even on the eighth before the calends of January, though the year was not the same.”
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: Robbery of damage is in that gathering, except a living robbery, namely seven years, and we were not wise, but we perceive now our position, namely, that the suffering of Christ was not prevented by the Jews. Then a great trembling came from the sky and earth and shook heaven and earth with that terrible deed, namely, Jesus Christ, Son of God, was crucified without guilt. “What is this?” said Conall to the druid. “What great evil happens on this day today?” “It is men from the otherworld,” said the druid. “This is a great deed,” said Conall. “That man did it,” said the druid, “in the autumn he will gain and you will lose, namely, in eight cold years of Enair without a drop of flood for a year.”
gemma_T0.2_K40_P0.85: Robbery of damage is in that gathering, except a living robbery, namely seven years, and we were not wise, but we foresee now our position, namely, that the guilt of Christ was crucified by the Jews. Then a great trembling came from the sky and the heavens and the earth shook with that terrible deed, namely, Jesus Christ, Son of God, was crucified without sin. “What is this?” said Conall to the druid. “What great evil happens on this day today?” “It is men from the otherworld,” said the druid. “This is a great deed,” said Conall. “That man did it,” said the druid, “in the eighth year of Enaer without a drop of water for a year.”
gemma_T0.5_K30_P0.85: Robbery of damage is in that gathering, a living robbery, namely seven years, and we were not wise, but we foresee now our position—namely, that the suffering of Christ was not repelled by the Jews. Then a great trembling came from the sky and earth and shook heaven and earth with that dreadful act, namely, Jesus Christ, Son of God, was crucified without guilt. “What is this?” said Conall to the druid. “What great evil happens on this day today?” “It is men from the otherworld,” said the druid. “This is a great deed,” said Conall. “That man did it,” said the druid, “in the autumn he will gain and you will lose—namely, in eight calends of November without a drop of water for a year.”
gemma_T1.0_K40_P0.9: Robbery of damage is in that gathering, a living robbery, namely seven years, and we were not wise, but we foresee now our position—namely, that the suffering of Christ was not repelled by the Jews. Then a great trembling came from the sky and earth and shook heaven and earth with that terrible deed, namely, Jesus Christ, Son of God, was crucified without guilt. “What is this?” said Conall to the druid. “What great evil happens on this day today?” “It is men from the otherworld,” said the druid. “This is a great deed,” said Conall. “That man did it,” said the druid, “in the autumn he will gain and regain—namely, in eight calends of November without a drop of water for a year.”

Irish: Is andsin rochreiti Conall. Ocus issé sin indara fer rochreti do Día i nHérinn ría tiachtain creitmi é .i. Morand in fer aile.
English: It was then that Conall believed. And he was one of the two men that had believed in God in Ireland before the coming of the Faith, Morann being the other man.
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: Then it was prophesied by Conall. And he was the second man to prophesy to God in Ireland, as long as prophecy shall endure, namely, Morann the other man.
gemma_T0.2_K40_P0.85: Then it was prophesied by Conall. And he was the second man to prophesy to God in Ireland, as long as prophecy shall be, namely, Morann the other man.
gemma_T0.5_K30_P0.85: Then it was prophesied by Conall. And he was the second man to prophesy to God in Ireland, as long as prophecy shall endure, namely, Morann the other man.
gemma_T1.0_K40_P0.9: Then it was prophesied by Conall. And he was the second man to prophesy to God in Ireland, as long as prophecy shall endure, namely, Morann the other man.

Irish: Ocus as iarsin asbert Conall: “Rofeasdais fir in beatha mo cumang ac cathugud fri hIudaidhibh tre crochad Críst dia mbeinn a comfogus dó.” Is iarsin attraacht ocus rosgobh forsin deargail cur’sceinn incinn Mesgeagra as a cinn ocus conearbailt Concubur fochétóir. Conadh [d]esin adber[a]t na Gæidhil conadh hé Concubur cétgeinntlide docóidh docum neimhi a nÉirinn, fobíth robo baithis dó in fuil dobidg as[a] cinn. Et as annsin rucadh ainim Conall a n ifrinn gu comraiced Críst fria ac te:uir na broide a hifrinn, co tuc Críst leis anim Conall docum neimhi. Finid.
English: And thereupon Conall said: “The men of the world would know what I can do in fighting against the Jews for the sake of the crucifixion of Christ, if I were near Him.” Then he rose and made the onslaught, until Mesgegra’s brains jumped out of his head, so that Conall died forthwith. Hence the Gaels say that Conall was the first pagan who went to Heaven in Ireland, for the blood that sprang out of his head was a baptism to him. And then Conall’s soul was taken to hell until Christ encountered her as He brought the captive host out of hell, so that Christ took the soul of Conall with Him to Heaven. Finit.
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: And then Conall spoke: “I would gladly give up my life and battle with the Jews through the sign of Christ if I were worthy of him.” And then a fierce and red flame was cast from the head of Mesgeagra and the head of Concubur the leper was split. Then the Gaels made a vow that Concubur of the hundred families would not return to Ireland, lest his soul be a torment to them. And from then on, Conall’s name went to hell to converse with Christ and to endure the torments of hell, until Christ took Conall’s soul to heaven. The end.
gemma_T0.2_K40_P0.85: And then Conall spoke: “I would gladly give up my life and battle with the Jews through the sign of Christ if I were worthy of him.” And then a fierce and red flame was cast from the head of Mesgeagra and the head of Concubur the leper was split. Then the Gaels made a vow that Concubur of the hundred families would not return to Ireland, lest his soul be a torment to them. And from then on, Conall’s name went to hell to converse with Christ and to endure the torments of hell, until Christ took Conall’s soul to heaven. The end.
gemma_T0.5_K30_P0.85: And then Conall spoke: “I would gladly give up my life and battle with the Jews through the cross of Christ if I were worthy of him.” And then a fierce and red flame was cast from the head of Mesgeagra and the head of Concubur the leper was split. Then the Gaels made a vow that Concubur of the hundred families would not return to Ireland, lest his soul be a torment to them. And from then on, Conall’s name went to hell to converse with Christ and to endure the torments of hell, until Christ took Conall’s soul to heaven. The end.
gemma_T1.0_K40_P0.9: And then Conall spoke: “I would wish the men of this life to be my champions and to fight against the Jews through the sign of Christ, if I were worthy of him.” And then a great and fierce redness was cast upon Mesgeagra’s head and the rebellion of Concubur the wretched. Thus did the Gaels say of Concubur, a hundred-sided man, who brought a heavenly judgment to Ireland, for it was a great loss to him to lose his head. And from then on, Conall’s soul went to hell to contend with Christ against him and to increase the torment of hell, until Christ took Conall’s soul to heaven. The end.

Irish: Intan bátar na ónmite ’co cluchiu do inchind Me[i]sgegra, issed atbert ind ónmit fri araile. Rocluinedar Cet aní sin. Ethaid side in n-inchind al-láim indala n-ái ocus berid leiss, ó rofitir Cet robói i tarngere do Messgegra a dígail iarna écaib. Cach cath ocus cach irga[l] nobíd do Chonnachtaib fri Ulto dobered Cet in n-inchind inna chriss dús in tetarthad écht n-amra d’ Ultaib do marbad di.
English: While the jesters (of Emain ) were at play with the brain of Mesgegra, this is what one jester said to the other. Cet hears that. He snatches the brain out of the hand of one of them, and carries it off; for he knew that it had been foretold of Mesgegra that he would avenge himself after his death. In every battle and in every combat which the men of Connaught had with those of Ulster, Cet used to carry the brain in his girdle to see whether he could compass a famous deed by slaying a man of Ulster with it.
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: Then were the provisions and games at the inauguration of Meisgegra, and a challenge was made from one provision to another. Cet plundered them after that. It was this inauguration that gave the over-lordship to the men of the land and water with him, for Cet was made a champion to defend Meisgegra after a hundred. Every battle and every hostage was taken from the Connachta in Ulster, and Cet gave this inauguration to them, so that the fourth part of Ulster was given for the slaying of them.
gemma_T0.2_K40_P0.85: Then were the provisions and games at the inauguration of Meisgegra, and a challenge was made from one provision to another. Cet plundered them after that. It was that inauguration which always held the sway and power of the drink and food with it, for Cet was a champion in the service of Meisgegra to avenge a hundred. Every battle and every exploit was refused to the Connachtmen against Ulster, and Cet took the inauguration into his own hand, so that a third part of the men of Ulster were killed by it.
gemma_T0.5_K30_P0.85: Then were the provisions and games at the inauguration of Meisgegra, and a challenge was made from one provision to another. Cet plundered it after that. It was this inauguration that gave the over-lordship to the men of Connacht over Ulster, for Cet destroyed the inauguration in the third year of his reign, and he was forced to go into exile from Ireland after seven years. Every battle and every exploit was refused to the men of Connacht against Ulster, until Cet destroyed this inauguration, and a third part of the men of Ulster were killed by him.
gemma_T1.0_K40_P0.9: Then were the provisions and games at the inauguration of Meisgegra, and a challenge was made from one provision to another. Cet plundered them after that. It was this inauguration that gave the over-lordship of the land and water to him, for Cet was made a champion to defend Meisgegra after a hundred. Every battle and every exploit was refused to the Connachta against Ulster, and Cet gave this inauguration to them, so that the fourth part of Ulster was given for the slaying of them.

Irish: Loích ro bátar do Mumab .i. Mac Connaid ocus Marrcán ocus Óengus. Is de ro chét: Ní thaet didiu de in cocad fri hOssairge, cen Mac Connaid for eoch án, cen Marccán, cen Óengus. Óengus ua Dimmae Chróin ro bí in fer isi[nd] móin; túirid na cholaind aile nícon rubae oenguine. Comaithig immorro do Óengus Huí Máil ocus ba holc immorro a chomaithcess doib. Is de ro chét: Huí Máil trícha cét ba hed a lín; nocon fhárgaib Óengus acht trí nónburu díb. A n-as·rubart fodessin: “Is cumma lim-sa huí Máil ocus muilenn oc blith gráin; it fáilte huí Máil fria nguin is cóir cach bró fria tuarcain.”
English: Mac Connaid, Marrcán and Óengus were three warriors of the men of Munster. It was sung of them: From Osraige our warband does not return without Mac Connaid on his noble horse, without Marrcán or Óengus. Óengus descendant of Dímmae Crón killed a man in the marsh: search his whole body for not one wound has struck him. Now Óengus’s neighbours were the Uí Máil and his neighbourship was bad indeed for them. Concerning this it was sung: The Uí Máil, three thousand were their number: Óengus left none but three times nine among them. Óengus himself said: “The Uí Máil and a mill grinding grain are both the same to me. the Uí Máil are welcome to the killings for every quern is proper for crushing.”
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: Loích was plundered in Mumhan, namely MacConaid, Marccan, and Óengus. And it was thus: they never left the assembly of Ossory without MacConaid being a single steed for them, without Marccan, without Óengus. Óengus son of Dímma of Cróin was the man most skilled in the bog; the peaks of the hills were not redder than his youthful face. A great host came to Óengus of the Uí Máil, and it was evil for them to encounter that host. And it was thus: the Uí Máil had thirty thousand, a good number; Óengus did not spare them except for three non-free men of them. They said this boastfully: “It is equal to me the Uí Máil and a mill with full grain; welcome to the Uí Máil to their wealth and fitting is every tribute to their host.”
gemma_T0.2_K40_P0.85: Loích was plundered in Mumhan, namely MacConaid, Marccan, and Óengus. And it was thus: they never left the assembly of Ossory without MacConaid being a single steed for them, without Marccan, without Óengus. Óengus son of Dímma of Cróin was the man most skilled in the bog; the peaks of the hills were not redder than his youthful face. A great host came to Óengus of the Uí Máil, and it was evil for them to encounter that host. And it was thus: the Uí Máil had thirty thousand, a good number; Óengus did not spare them except for three score of them. They said this boastfully: “It is equal to me the Uí Máil and a mill with full grain; welcome to the Uí Máil to their wealth and fitting is every tribute to their host.”
gemma_T0.5_K30_P0.85: Loích was plundered in Mumhan, namely MacConaid, Marccan, and Óengus. And it was thus: they never left the hosting of Ossory without MacConaid being a single steed, without Marccan, without Óengus. Óengus son of Dímma Croyne was the man most skilled in the bog; the breasts of the women were not red with Óengus’s gold. A great host came to Óengus son of Máel, and it was evil for them to encounter that host. And it was thus: the sons of Máel were thirty thousand strong; Óengus did not spare but three score of them. Their boast was this: “It is equal to me the sons of Máel and a mill with full grain; welcome are the sons of Máel to my wealth and fitting is every tribute to my hosting.”
gemma_T1.0_K40_P0.9: Loích was plundered in Mumhan, namely MacConaid, Marccan, and Óengus. And it was thus: they never left the hosting of Ossory without MacConaid being a single steed, without Marccan, without Óengus. Óengus son of Dímma Croyne was the man most skilled in the bog; the breasts of the women were not red with Óengus’s gold. A great host came to Óengus son of Máel, and it was evil for them to encounter that host. And it was thus: the sons of Máel were thirty thousand strong; Óengus did not spare but three score of them. Their boast was this: “It is equal to me the sons of Máel and a mill with full grain; welcome are the sons of Máel to my wealth and fitting is every tribute to my hosting.”

Irish: Athechda rí hua Máil immorro. Do·fuc Óengus a ingin. Luid-si didiu fecht do thig a [h]athar do chomfhis a mmáthar bae i ngalur. Ro aslacht a hathair fuirri-se brathtecosc a fir dó. “Maith,” ar [in] ben, “fil mo dáil-se fris i-nnocht. Acht a·taat teora huarbotha lais ocus ní fetar-sa ciasu adba díb i fifa i-nnocht, acht ro·fetar-sa a n-as maith duib. Tucthar lib lán mo chlera-sa do thenid sinnaig ocus at·bér-sa is é m’étach-sa fil ann ocus biat-sa ina diaid et láifet-sa in tenid im diaid, ocus toít-si iarmo shlicht.”
English: Now Aithechda was the king of the Uí Máil. Óengus married his daughter. Once she went to the house of her father to visit her mother, who was sick. Her father persuaded her that it was fitting to betray Óengus . “That is good,” said the woman, “I am meeting with him tonight. There are three huts near him and I do not know in which of them he will sleep during the night but I know the best course for you. Bring my bag full of fox-fire and I will tell him that my dress is inside it: I will follow after him, then you throw the fox-fire behind me and follow in my path.”
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: The king of the Uí Máil was taken unawares. Óengus took his daughter. He lay long in contention with his father for his comfort and his mother was in a cold place. His father slew his warrior for him. “Good,” said the woman, “fulfill my share with you tonight. But there are fierce men with you and I will not let you have a single bite of them tonight, but I will let their best be given to you. You shall have the full of my treasure and the portion of that woman, and I will be his pledge and I will follow after him in that portion, and she will take a simple yoke.”
gemma_T0.2_K40_P0.85: The king of the Uí Máil was taken unawares. Óengus fostered his daughter. She lay long in contention with her father for her mother’s portion. Her father slew a brave man for her sake. “Good,” said the woman, “fulfill my share tonight. But there are fierce, cold men with you and I will not let any of them near you tonight, but I will let the best of you go. You shall have your fill of my tears and then I will take what is my due, and I will go after it, and she took a simple yoke.”
gemma_T0.5_K30_P0.85: The king of the Uí Máil was taken unawares. Óengus took his daughter. He lay long in contention with his father for his mother’s comfort, she being in a state of hardship. His father slew his rival, a skilled warrior, with his people. “Good,” said the woman, “fulfill my share with you tonight. But there are fierce, cold winds with you and I will not allow any deceit from you tonight, but I will allow your better deeds. You shall have the fullness of my wealth and possessions for that deed, and I will be your pledge for it, and I will follow after you in that deed, and she took a simple yoke.”
gemma_T1.0_K40_P0.9: The king of the Uí Máil was taken unawares. Óengus took his daughter. He lay long in contention with his father for his mother’s comfort, she being in a state of hardship. His father slew his rival, a skilled warrior, with his people. “Good,” said the woman, “fulfill my share with you tonight. But there are fierce, cold men with you and I will not let you touch them tonight, but I will let my best men at you. You shall have your fill of my tears and lamentation for that deed, and I will be your atonement for it, and I will follow after you until I have avenged it, and she took a simple yoke.”

Irish: Ba fír ón. Tiagait co mbátar immun n-uarboith. Con·gairet fair. “Innat-fhail tall, a Oengus?” “Cosmail mo bith,” ar Óengus, “ocus ná marbaid for siair. Nos léicebh chucaib.” “Mo chen di,” ar ind óic. La sodain lomraid a c(h)ennchongraim na mmná ocus do·beir immo chenn fesin ocus luid secco samlaid. “Robbar bia imned,” ar ei-sseom, “i-fecht-sa lim-sa. Mo ben-sa ocus for n-ingen féin ro marbsaid.” Ocus ros fuabair coro lá a n-ár in tan sin. Do·gní iarum Óengus ocus Aithechda córai dib línaib.
English: So it happened. [The sons of Aithechda] went until they were near the hut and they called to him,  “Are you there, Óengus?” “It is likely that I am,” he replied. “Do not kill your sister:  I shall allow her to come out to you.” “That is well with us,” the young men said. With that Óengus stripped the shawl from the woman, put it about his own head and so made his way past them. *With that, they attacked the hut and killed the person inside it. Then he called from behind them: “I will make you regret that now,” he said. “You have killed my wife and your own sister.”* Then he set upon the men and slaughtered them. Afterwards Óengus and Aithechda made peace.
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: It is true. They came until they were near us in the wood. A hound barked. “Is it a noble fall, Oengus?” “My life is weary,” said Oengus, “and let not death be for a woman. A night I will spend with them.” “I know that,” said the young boy. Then suddenly the tops of the women’s heads were seen and they brought a head with them and laid it quietly in a shroud. “I stole food for my need,” said the phantom, “it is fitting for me with you. My head and for a maiden herself was killed.” And it was cold for a day after that time. Then Oengus and Aithechda prepared lines for them.
gemma_T0.2_K40_P0.85: It is true. Tig came with a boat towards us across the water. A hound barked. “Is it a noble fall, Oengus?” “My life is weary,” said Oengus, “and let not death be for a woman. A night I will spend with you.” “I know that,” said the young boy. Then suddenly a violent spasm seized the heads of the women and they brought their own heads to me and laid them quietly side by side. “I stole food unjustly,” said the woman-phantom, “it is a shame to be with me. My own head and the head of my own daughter were killed.” And it was cold for a day after that time. Then Oengus and Aithechda prepared lines for them.
gemma_T0.5_K30_P0.85: It is true. Tig came with a boat towards us across the water. A hound barked. “Is it a noble fall, Oengus?” “My life is weary,” said Oengus, “and let not death be for a woman. A night I will spend with companions.” “I know that,” said the young boy. Then suddenly a violent spasm seized the heads of the women and they carried their own heads with them and lay lifeless in a heap. “I stole food unjustly,” said the phantom, “it is a poor fate for me. My own head and for a maiden indeed I died.” And it was cold for a day after that time. Then Oengus and Aithechda prepared lines for them.
gemma_T1.0_K40_P0.9: It is true. They came until they were near us in the wood. A hound barked. “Is it a noble fall, Oengus?” “Such is my fate,” said Oengus, “and let it not be for a woman. A night I will spend with them.” “I know that,” said the young boy. Then suddenly the tops of the women’s breasts were uncovered and they bore their own heads and lay lifelessly. “I stole food unjustly,” said the phantom, “it is a poor thing with me. My own head and for a maiden indeed I died.” And it was cold for a day after that time. Then Oengus and Aithechda made a covering for them with branches.

Irish: tánaic in chaillech reimpi co Colmán ocus ro ghab in rann do:— “A Colmán in imráidi . imghlasad iar nimbáini? seis duit t’aenarán cin nech . in núir aidhne” “A mendocán imráidim . ocus dna cáin innláidim; cech aen [dar] ráinic a les . ní dechaid cin domainches” “Is é mo domainchessa” ar sí “m’aenmhacán.” “fogabasa sin dana” or Colmán “ocus digéltair sin for Aena.”
English: The old woman went straight to Colmán, and sang the quatrain at him, thus:— “Considerest thou, Colmán, the turning livid that follows the first mere growing pale? be certified of this: that all alone and without a fellow thou shalt yet dwell under mould of aidhne” *Said Colmán:— “I think of it often enough, and, indeed, my indulgence is that anyone who needs relief, will not go away without their petition being granted.”* She went on: “my petition is for my only little son”; and Colmán answered: “thou shalt have him, *indeed,* but Aena shall be avenged for this.”
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: The old woman went seeking Colmán and he gave the verse to her:— “O Colmán of the wandering! Were you cold after the clouds? Choose for yourself a portion of wealth. The young woman is fair.” “O little wanderer, I wander, and I make a lawful request; each portion that is given to me, it is not the portion of Sunday.” “It is my Sunday portion,” said he, “my only portion.” “Refuse that to her,” said Colmán, “and it will be a freezing for Aena.”
gemma_T0.2_K40_P0.85: The old woman went seeking Colmán and he gave the verse to her:— “O Colmán of the wandering! Were clouds after your baptism? Choose your single portion of worth. The young lady is bright.” “O wandering mendicant! And I give my daily tribute; each single thing that I see, I will not refuse a single lord.” “It is my lordship,” said she, “my single one.” “Abandon that then,” said Colmán, “and it will be cold for Aena.”
gemma_T0.5_K30_P0.85: The old woman went seeking Colmán and he gave the verse to her:— “O Colmán of the wandering! Were you cold after the clouds? Choose for yourself a portion of wealth. The young woman is beautiful.” “O wandering mendicant! And I give a kiss of welcome; every single one that comes to me, I will not refuse a Sunday’s portion.” “That is my Sunday’s portion,” said she, “my only portion.” “Open your mouth for that,” said Colmán, “and it will be a freezing thing for Aena.”
gemma_T1.0_K40_P0.9: The old woman went seeking Colmán and then gave the verse to him:— “O Colmán of the wandering! Were you cold after the clouds? Choose for yourself a portion of wealth. The young woman is beautiful.” “O little wanderer, I wander, and I make a lawful payment; each portion that is given to me, I will not take on Sundays.” “My Sunday is this,” said she, “my only portion.” “Refuse that from her,” said Colmán, “and it will be a freezing for Aena.”

Irish: ba fíor són. ro marb bachlach do muinntir Chluana ech Aena ocá thafunn as a ghort. ro gabad in bachlach oc Aena corro naidmed cét mbó ar in mbachlach i níc in eich. táinic in bachlach ar sin co Colmán dá faighde. “gab in rannsa do Aena” ar Colmán.
English: And that was true: for a certain churl of the familia of Clonmacnoise chasing Aena’s horse out of his field killed him, and Aena, after having said churl seized, in satisfaction of the horse laid on him a fine of one hundred cows; whereupon the common fellow for comfort repairing to Colmán, the king said: “to Aena recite this quatrain.”
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: It was a true loss. A small boy of Cluain Ech Aena died from his injury. Aena seized the boy, and a hundred cows were demanded for the boy, not for a horse. The boy went then to Colmán to obtain [something]. “Take the portion from Aena,” said Colmán.
gemma_T0.2_K40_P0.85: It was a true loss. A small boy of Cluain Ech Aena died from his injury. Aena seized the boy, and a hundred cows were demanded for the boy, not for a horse. The boy went then to Colmán to obtain [something]. “Take the portion from Aena,” said Colmán.
gemma_T0.5_K30_P0.85: It was a true loss. A small boy of the people of Cluain Ech Aena died from his wound. Aena seized the boy, and a hundred cows were demanded for the boy, not for a horse. The boy went then to Colmán to get satisfaction. “Take the portion from Aena,” said Colmán.
gemma_T1.0_K40_P0.9: It was a true loss. A small boy of the people of Cluain Ech Aena died from his wound. Aena seized the boy, and ninety cows were seized with the boy, not the horses. The boy went then to Colmán to seek help. “Take the portion to Aena,” said Colmán.

Irish: tánaic in bachlach reime co hAena ocus do gab in rann .i. Tháinig fear an ghoirt roimhe chun Aena agus do ghabh sé an rann: “Do mac Laígse ba mór gó . in aenchenn ar in cét mbó; in mór do dul ar in mbec . in fubann in tsacairbec” “Is fuba imorro” ol Aena: “ní iarrubsa fortsa acht aenbhó.” ro búi dana a leithéite sin co meinic itir Aena ocus Colmán.
English: The churl came to Aena, and delivered the quatrain:— “Great falsehood [i.e. an iniquitous award] it was for mac Laígse that a single head [i.e. one animal] should be made to represent an hundred kine; that the much should pass in payment for the little *does that impair the sacred host (i.e. vitiate thy sacred profession)?”*“Verily,” Aena said, “it is an iniquity, and I will ask of thee but one cow.” Now this kind of thing often passed between Colmán and him.
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: The leper hastened to Aena and recited the verse, namely: “The son of Laeg was great and noble; a hundred cows were his wealth; great is going on a small journey; the fleece is on the small sheep.” “It is a burden,” said Aena: “I will not ask for strength but for one cow.” Then a dispute arose often between Aena and Colmán.
gemma_T0.2_K40_P0.85: The leper hastened to Aena and recited the verse, namely: “The son of Laeg was great and generous; a hundred cows were his wealth; great was his going for a small calf; the fleece was the small calf’s reward.” “It is a poor reward,” said Aena: “I will not ask for more than one cow.” Then, because of that generosity, frequent visits occurred between Aena and Colmán.
gemma_T0.5_K30_P0.85: The leper hastened to Aena and recited the verse, namely: “The son of Laeg was great and noble; a hundred cows were his wealth; great is going on a small journey; the fleece is on the small sheep.” “It is a burden,” said Aena: “I will not ask for strength but for one cow.” Then a dispute arose often between Aena and Colmán.
gemma_T1.0_K40_P0.9: The leper hastened to Aena and recited the verse, namely: “The son of Laeg was great and generous; a hundred cows were his wealth; great was his going for a small measure; the fleece was the small sack.” “It is a burden,” said Aena: “I will not ask for strength but for one cow.” Then a dispute arose often between Aena and Colmán.

Irish: Fecht ann, bae Óengus ic fothrucud hi tich Aithechdai ocus bae for menmain dó-side a marbad-som. (Ní bae dano Dubchrón gilla Óengus ann in tan-sin.) Mus léc fer díb aigen láin gríscha moa súili ocus moa aigid ocus clannaid Athechda a gae fodessin ind (.i. in Charr Óengus) co mbaí triit conarro marbsat samlaid. Benait iarom a chenn de ocus do·berar hé for a dérgud ocus bratt dar a chenn. Do·rooig Dubchrón for Dubglais .i. for a gabair-seom. “Tairling, a Dubchróin,” ar cách. “Níthó,” ar Dubchrón. “Cate Óengus?” “A·tá inna chotlud; sit, sit, ar nácha ndúsca. Tairling ocus tair ’sin tech.” “Ní dóig limm a chotlud acht má beind-se coa aire. Gataid in mbratt dia aigid,” ar se. Gattair de. “Fír, a Óengus ,” ar sé. Ocus dixit: “Deithbir dond aigid cid bán cond·ránic fri faeburdán; imma·rulaid ilar lám in cenn fil for Óengus.”
English: Another time Óengus was bathing in the house of Aithechda and it was in Aithechda’s mind to kill him. *However* Dubchrón, Óengus’s servant, was not there on this occasion. One of the men present quickly tipped a pan *full* of embers into the eyes *and face* of Óengus and Aithechda thrust Óengus’s own spear into him *so that it went through him* and so killed him. Then, they stuck off his head and placed him on a bed with a cloak over his head. Dubchrón arrived on Dubglas, Óengus’s horse. “Get down, Dubchrón,” they all said. “No,” he replied, “Where is Óengus?” “Hush, *hush,* he is asleep — do not disturb him. Dismount and come over into the house.” “It is not likely that Óengus would rest unless I were watching over him. Remove the cloak from his face.” It was removed. “So it is true, Óengus,” he said: “Though it is white it befits the face, that has met with swordplay. The head of Óengus has passed through many hands.”
gemma_T0.1_K30_P0.7: There was a seizure there, the household of Óengus son of Fothrud was in the house of Aithechda, and a great lament was made on both sides about his killing. (It was not unknown to Dubchrón, the foster-son of Óengus, at that time.) Before a man of them would speak a grey word with my eye and my face and the people of Aithechda would go to dwell there (that is, in Carr Óengus) until three attempts at killing were made. He bent his head downwards and he carried him on his back and a cloak was over his head. Dubchrón went for Dubglais, that is, for his companion. “Rise up, Dubchrón,” said someone. “I will not,” said Dubchrón. “Where is Óengus?” “He is in his bed; sit, sit, lest he wake. Rise up and rise to the house.” “I do not believe his bed unless I am with care. Take the cloak from his face,” he said. He took it off. “Truly, Óengus,” he said. And he said: “Send forth your face, a white mark against a small shield; let a king’s head be placed in Óengus’ hand.”
gemma_T0.2_K40_P0.85: There was a seizure there, the household of Óengus son of Fothrud was in the house of Aithechda, and a great lament was made on both sides about his killing. (It was not unknown to Dubchrón, the foster-son of Óengus, at that time.) Before a man of them would speak a grey word with my eye and my face and the people of Aithechda would go to dwell there (that is, in Carr Óengus) until three attempts at killing were made. He cursed his head afterwards and it was carried off for his redness and a cloak was over his head. Dubchrón was ruined for Dubglais, that is, for his taking. “Awake, Dubchrón,” said someone. “Not yet,” said Dubchrón. “Where is Óengus?” “He is in his little house; sit, sit, lest he awaken. Awake and awake to the house.” “I do not believe his little house unless I am with attention. Take the cloak from his face,” he said. He took it. “Truly, Óengus,” he said. And he said: “Let your face be taken away, white, with a small branch on a shield for Óengus.”
gemma_T0.5_K30_P0.85: There was a seizure there, the household of Óengus son of Fothrud was in the house of Aithechda, and a great lament was made on both sides about his killing. (It was not unknown to Dubchrón, the foster-son of Óengus, at that time.) Before a man of them would speak a grey word with my eye and my face and the people of Aithechda would go to dwell there (i.e. in Carr Óengus) until three attempts at killing were made. He cursed his head afterwards and it was carried off for his redness and a cloak was over his head. Dubchrón was ruined for Dubglais, i.e. for his own destruction. “Rise up, Dubchrón,” said someone. “I will not,” said Dubchrón. “Where is Óengus?” “He is in his little house; sit, sit, lest he awaken. Rise up and rise to the house.” “I do not believe his little house unless there is someone watching. Take the cloak over his face,” he said. He took it. “Truly, Óengus,” he said. And he said: “Bring your face, white as quicklime, to the edge of the board; let many a hand be on the head of the man who is for Óengus.”
gemma_T1.0_K40_P0.9: There was a seizure there, the household of Óengus son of Fothrud was in the house of Aithechda, and a great lament was made on both sides about his killing. (It was not unknown to Dubchrón, the foster-son of Óengus, at that time.) No man of them dared look at my face or my eye or the people of Aithechda until they went to that place (namely, to the stone of Óengus) until three attempts at killing were made. He bent his head down and they carried him out for his redness and a cloak was over his head. Dubchrón went for Dubglais, namely, for his playmate. “Rise up, Dubchrón,” said someone. “I will not,” said Dubchrón. “Where is Óengus?” “He is in his little house; sit, sit, lest he awaken. Rise up and rise to the house.” “I do not believe in his little house unless someone is watching. Take the cloak from his eye,” he said. He took it off. “Truly, Óengus,” he said. And he said: “Bring your eye, white as quicklime, to the edge of the board; let many a head fall for Óengus’ sake.”
